body: @marco-c From where should this data be extracted? (Any specific field that should be used?)
The data should be extracted from commits, using a template when calling hg.log.

I think the first step would be to try to add the `template` parameter to the `hg.log` call and adjust the rest of the code.

E.g. template='{author}|{node}\n'
will give you something like:
```
Masayuki Nakano <masayuki@d-toybox.com>|c650507f7feee04516c2c869a2f0662c2a6dc0c0
Kartikaya Gupta <kgupta@mozilla.com>|47b5e6d95d9eaa421b6aaaccd8f263f32bbc8121
Brian Grinstead <bgrinstead@mozilla.com>|5ea2f61028a5e989f1dbf46e9fe961a7b1c419ca
```

I just dug a bit into the hglib code, looks like using `hg.log()` returns commit in `'{rev}\\0{node}\\0{tags}\\0{branch}\\0{author}\\0{desc}\\0{date}\\0'` format. Can't we use this directly? `commit.author` and `commit.node` attributes can be used to extract the corresponding values.
We can use it for the author, we can't use it for the reviewer.

@marco-c I'm trying to do something like:
```
>>> import hglib
>>> hg = hglib.open("mozilla-central")
```

`hg` in this case doesn't have a kwarg called template, according to the docs. What am I doing wrong? (Is there some problem in installing the extension?)

Ahhh, that's a pity. I thought there was a `template` parameter for log.

OK, so it looks like you'll have to write a custom log function, you can take inspiration from https://www.mercurial-scm.org/repo/python-hglib/file/tip/hglib/client.py#l1095.
(you don't need to support all the options, just template)

The default template is defined in `templates.changeset`, equal to `'{rev}\\0{node}\\0{tags}\\0{branch}\\0{author}\\0{desc}\\0{date}\\0'`, so if I try to change that, I get an empty list in the result, so maybe the template `{author}|{node}\n` isn't right?
```
>>> import hglib
>>> from hglib import templates
>>> templates.changeset = '{author}|{node}\n'
>>> hg = hglib.open('mozilla-central')
>>> hg.log(limit=5000)
[ ]
```

> maybe the template {author}|{node}\n isn't right?

You can test it from the command line, `hg log --template '{author}|{node}\n'`.
Hm, that's weird. I'm not sure why it behaves differently in both cases.
You should try to reimplement `hg.log`, if you just change `templates.changeset` it's not going to work as the parsing code assumes the template is the default one.

For example:
```python
import hglib
from hglib.util import cmdbuilder

c = hglib.open('/home/calixte/dev/mozilla/mozilla-central.hg')
args = cmdbuilder(b'log', template='{author}\\0{node}\\0', r="tip:-2")
x = c.rawcommand(args)
c.close()
print(x)
```

is working for me.

issue.title: templated log function

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
Created a new class, derived from `hgclient`, and the log function now has a `template` parameter. 
Initial fix for #105

body: @marco-c Now that the first step is complete (template for log function), how should the experience of the author be determined? (Probably depends on the number of commits made?)
Yes, it should be the number of commits by that author in total and in the previous three months.

rename.from: Add `author experience` and `reviewer experience` as features

body: I've split the issue in two, this one is about the author, #152 is about the reviewer.

> Yes, it should be the number of commits by that author in total and in the previous three months.

Sure, so we can have a global variable such as `num_commits = {}` that maps author names to the number of commits made by them, and then writes it out to the json file?
We'll add the information directly in commits.json (each commit will have `author_experience` and `author_experience_past_3_months`).

issue.title: Add total author experience

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
Initial fix for #105 .

The `_transform` function now updates the number of commits per author on each iteration, and `_add_experience` adds this information to the data.

body:
Total author experience has been added with #154.

Now we need to add author experience in previos 3 months.
